Fig. 1 XRD patterns of (a) commercial TiO2 supports, (b) Ru/TiO2 catalysts, (c and d) zoom of highlighted zones. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 H2 -TPR profiles for Ru/TiO2-P25 treated in synthetic air or hydrogen. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM micrographs and particle size distribution for reduced Ru/TiO2-P25 treated with (a) synthetic air, (b) hydrogen, (c) distribution of metal Ru particles. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Oxidative and/or reductive atmosphere effect on selective methanation of CO with Ru/TiO2-P25. Feed composition: 1%CO, 15% CO2, 50%H2 (balance N2); WHSV: 80,000 mL.g−1.h−1. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) XRD pattern for Ru/TiO2-P25 samples treated at different temperatures with synthetic air, (b) zoom between 2θ = 27° and 36.5°, (c) zoom between 2θ = 27° and 29°. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Raman spectra for Ru/TiO2-P25 samples treated at different temperatures with synthetic air (A: Anatase TiO2, R: Rutile TiO2, RuO2: Rutile RuO2). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2 -TPR profiles for Ru/TiO2-P25 samples treated at different temperatures. (reducibility percentages at the upper right). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Calcination temperature effect on selective methanation of CO with Ru/TiO2-P25 previously treated with synthetic air. Feed composition: 1%CO, 15% CO2, 50%H2 (balance N2); WHSV: 80,000 mL.g−1.h−1. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 in situ Raman spectra for methanation with different atmospheres on Ru/TiO2-P25 at 220 ºC. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 in-situ XRD in synthetic air with the increasing calcination temperature for (a) TiO2-P25, (b) 5%Ru/TiO2-P25, (c) 10%Ru/TiO2-P25, (d) 20%Ru/TiO2-P25. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Ru loading effect on selective methanation of CO with Ru/TiO2-P25 previously treated with synthetic air at 400 °C. Feed composition: 1%CO, 15% CO2, 50%H2 (balance N2); WHSV: 80,000 mL.g−1.h−1. Fig. 11 Table 1 Comparative conditions and CO conversion temperatures. Table 1 Catalysts Conditions SCO methanation. The aim of this work was to clarify the effect of the support on CO selective methanation with Ru/TiO2 catalysts. TPR, XRD and TEM measurements confirmed that the changes in the activity and selectivity should be ascribed to anatase:rutile ratio, RuO2 +TiO2 solid solution formation, as well as the metal content and the thermal treatment used. All these characteristics result in active and selective catalysts in which the suppression of the reverse water gas shift reaction was observed. The catalytic performance must be explained by both the formation of more active Ru species as a result of support influence and the higher Ru dispersion. The study allows to conclude that for CO activation the role of support surface hydroxyls seems to be determinant for both the activity and selectivity of Ru/TiO2 catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ru/TiO2 catalysts TiO2 rutile TiO2 anatase RuO2 rutile CO methanation CO2 methanation Support surface hydroxyls 1 Introduction Selective methanation of CO (Eq. 1) in H2-rich gas mixtures is an interesting alternative to the commonly used preferential oxidation of CO (PROX reaction, Eq. 2) to selectively remove small amounts of CO from H2 rich feed gases for low-temperature polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs) [1–4]. Since these feed gases are often obtained from reforming hydrocarbons or biomass, and after Water Gas Shift (WGS) units, they also contain signiﬁcant amounts of CO2 in addition to CO. Therefore, the reaction has to be highly selective for the methanation of CO, as the methanation of CO2 (Eq. 3) would lead to intolerable losses of H2. (1) CO + 3 H2 ↔ CH4 + H2O ΔHº= −206 Kj/mol (2) CO + O2↔ CO2 ΔHº=−283 KJ/mol (3) CO2 + 4 H2↔CH4 + 2 H2O ΔHº= −165 Kj/mol Among other, textural properties, active metal particle size, reducibility properties and metal dispersion play significant roles in the optimization of industrial catalysts formulations, as these parameters directly affect the transfer of reactants and products in the catalyst. Reducible metal oxides have been widely used as support materials. Among them, TiO2 is known for its high stability, high ultraviolet absorption, and semiconductor properties which allow its use in various applications in catalysis and photocatalysis [5]. Furthermore, the existence of various crystalline phases of TiO2 contributes to catalytic performance in heterogeneous catalysis through morphologic and electronic changes. TiO2 is an efficient support for noble metal catalysts including Pd, Ru and Rh in CO and CO2 methanation [6,7]. Particularly, TiO2-supported RuO2 nanoparticles have shown excellent methanation capability [8–10]. The activity and selectivity of Ru catalysts to CH4 have been claimed to be largely dependent on the dispersion, the concentration and the particle size of the metal phase. Previous studies have demonstrated that both activity and particularly the selectivity of Ru catalysts strongly depends on Ru particle size, achieving 100% of selectivity in CO2-rich reformate gases down to very low CO concentrations [11]. Panagiotopoulou et. al [12] used supported ruthenium catalysts from 0.5 to 5.0 wt% for the selective methanation of CO in the presence of excess CO2. Conversion of CO2 was completely suppressed until conversion of CO reached its maximum value. Increasing metal loading resulted in a significant shift of the CO conversion curves towards lower temperatures with a lower participation of the Reverse Water Gas Shift reaction (RWGS, Eq. 4). (4) CO2 + H2↔ CO + H2O ΔHº= 41 Kj/mol Optimal results were obtained with 5 w/w% Ru on TiO2 catalyst with a mean crystallite size of 13.6 nm against 1.3 nm for 0.5 w/w% Ru. High Ru loading was able to convert CO completely and selectively at temperatures around 230 °C. Takenaka et. al [13] found an opposite trend. They proposed Ni/ZrO2 and Ru/TiO2 as promising catalysts based on a screening experiment and concluded that the larger Ni and the smaller Ru were the responsible of the high catalytic activity. Table 1 shows comparative conditions to provide a panoramic overview with some works that relate the Ru content with the temperature to achieve highest CO conversion and selectivity towards methane. Metal-support interactions (MSI) can modify the catalytic properties of the metal phase and therefore, the nature of the support plays a crucial role in the reaction pathway. Different studies on the crystal phase effect of TiO2 on the structure and performance of Ru nanoparticles in CO2 hydrogenation have been reported. For instance, Debeckera et.al [14] demonstrated the strong impact of the support crystal structure on Ru dispersion and on methanation activity. Rutile TiO2 was identified as promising support as a result of the strong interaction that it can develop with RuO2, as both has the same crystalline structure [10]. However, the use of rutile TiO2 is limited by its low specific surface area. The impact of the structure–activity relationships in Ru based catalysts has given rise to various preparation methods for well-dispersed and/or uniformly-sized nanoparticles of Ru and RuO2 for many catalytic applications in hydrogenation reactions [10–17]. Balaraju et al. [18] have shown the superior catalytic performances of Ru/TiO2 catalysts prepared by a deposition– precipitation method compared with those prepared by a conventional impregnation one, which was attributed to the presence of well-dispersed nano-sized Ru particles- Also, Sassoye et al. [19] have reported the synthesis of 2 nm RuO2 nanoparticles and the preparation of Ru/TiO2 catalysts after reduction under H2. Such catalysts demonstrated superior catalytic performance in CO2 methanation. Because of their well-known tendency of exhibiting higher selectivity and activity in selective CO methanation, in this work we used a set of Ru/TiO2 supported catalysts with widely varying TiO2 surface areas with different crystalline structures. We verify whether higher activity can be explained by the formation of more active Ru species or whether it is simply governed by dispersion (or both). Commercial TiO2 supports are explored in an attempt to separate the crystalline structural eﬀect from thermal stability against sintering. Diﬀerent approaches where the metal crystallite size was modified in a very controlled way, namely, different Ru loadings (2%, 5%, 10% and 20%.wt), different calcination temperatures (300ºC, 400ºC, 450ºC and 600ºC) or different thermal treatment (synthetic air and/or hydrogen) are studied. The relationships between CO hydrogenation activity and physicochemical properties of the dispersed metal phase are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts Ru/TiO2 catalysts were prepared using commercially TiO2 supports: TiO2-P25 (Aeroxide P25, Evonik, 80:20 anatase: rutile), TiO2-G5 (anatase G5 from Millenium calcined at 450ºC), TiO2-DT51 (anatase DT51 from Millenium), TiO2-(R+A) (80:20 TiO2-DT51:TiO2 rutile from Johnson Matthey physical mixture). The adequate amount of Ruthenium (III) nitrosyl nitrate solution (Johnson Matthey) was diluted in water and further added to 1 g of commercial TiO2 supports to form a suspension. At the beginning the Ru loading was fixed at 5.0 w/w%. The resulting slurry was kept under agitation for 15 min and afterwards the solvent was removed at reduced pressure in a rotavapor. Prior to any thermal treatment the resulting solid was dried at 130 °C for 30 min. To activate the catalysts thermal treatments under either synthetic air or hydrogen was performed at 450ºC for 2 h at 10 °C.min−1 heating ramp. Physicochemical characteristics of TiO2 support and after Ru addition are shown in Table 2. 2.2 Characterization techniques X-Ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometry was carried out in an X Panalytical AXIOS PW4400 equipped with a Rh tube as excitation source for determining the catalyst chemical compositions. A X`Pert Pro PANalytical. Diffraction instrument was utilized for recording the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns using Cu Kα radiation (40 mA, 45 kV) in [20º,80°] 2ϴ-range and a position-sensitive detector (0.05° step size and 80 s step time). Raman spectra of catalysts were recorded in a dispersive Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRam HR800 microscope with a He–Ne green laser (532.14 nm) working at 5 mW, and with a 600 g mm−1 grating. The microscope used a 50 × objective and a confocal pinhole of 1000 µm. The Raman spectrometer was calibrated using a silicon wafer. For in-situ Raman spectroscopy, a Linkam CCR100 cell was coupled to the Raman equipment. The microscope used a 20x objective and a confocal pinhole of 1000 µm. The catalysts were previously pretreated at 300 °C using 10 mL. min−1 H2 pure for 30 min and then the catalysts were studied under different methanation reaction atmospheres. TEM analysis was performed in a Philips CM 200 equipment working at 200 kV with EDS analysis and CCD camera. The textural properties were analyzed by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at liquid nitrogen temperature. The experiments were carried out on a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 instruments. The system was previously degassed during 2 h at 250 °C in vacuum. Pore size distribution was calculated using the Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) method on the desorption branch. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out in a conventional quartz reactor connected to a TCD detector. The reactive gas stream (5% H2 in Ar) was flowed at 50 mL/min over 50 mg of sample, and the temperature raised at 10 °C/min from room temperature to 700 °C. A CO2-acetone trap was used to condense the gaseous products evolved, mostly water. Quantitative analyses were done by integration of the reduction signal and comparison with hydrogen consumption of a CuO reference sample. To obtain the reducibility percentage, the loading of RuO2 was taken from XRF results and a theoretical molar ratio RuO2:H2 1:2 was considered. For H2-chemisorption a Micromeritics Autochem II equipment was used. The catalysts were heated in 5% H2 in Ar atmosphere until 300 °C (45 min). Then the temperature was decreased to 75 °C. At this temperature H2-pulses were carried out. For the quantification a 2/1 molar ratio of H2-chemisorbed vs total amount of Ru atoms was considered (H/Ru). 2.3 Catalytic activity Catalytic activity tests were performed in a Microactivity PID Eng & Tech instrument. The catalyst (150 mg, 100 < ϕ < 200 µm) was diluted in the adequate amount of silicon carbide sieved to a similar particle size and placed between quartz wool forming a 5 mm fixed bed in a 9 mm internal diameter tubular stainless-steel reactor (Autoclave Engineers). Before reaction the samples were activated in-situ at 300 °C for 2 h in 60 mL/min of pure H2 flow, purged with N2, and then conditioned at 140 °C for 1 h within the reaction mixture. A 200 mL.min−1 total flow reactant mixture consisting of 1% CO, 15% CO2, 50% H2, 15% H2O and N2 as balance simulating the outlet of reformer-WGS fuel processors was always used. The WHSV was fixed at 80,000 mL.g−1.h−1. The methanation flow was selected simulating CO-rich reformate gases from WGS units (H2 excess, CO2 presence and 1% CO concentration) and the activity for SCO methanation was studied from 140 ºC to 300 ºC in order to avoid RWGS reaction and to decrease the CO2 methanation. For the catalytic study, the reactant and products were analyzed by on-line gas chromatography (GC) using a two channel Varian µGC 4900 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a Vaisala Carbocap GMT220 detector for CO2. CO and CO2 conversions (XCO, XCO2), and selectivity to CO methanation (S) were defined as (Eqs. 5 to 7). (5) X CO % = F COin − F COout F COin * 100 (6) X CO 2 % = F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out F CO 2 in * 100 (7) S CO CO 2 % = X CO * F COin F CH 4 out Being F CO , F CO 2 and F CH 4 the flows in mL/min of CO, CO2 and methane respectively, the subscripts in or out correspond to the inlet or the outlet flow. In all cases, the methane selectivity, defined as Eq. 8, was higher than 95% and only traces of ethane and ethylene were detected. The carbon balance resulted to be better than 97%. (8) S tw CH 4 % = C CH 4 , out / υ CH 4 ∑ i C i , out / υ i * 100 C i , out is the product i concentration in the outlet and ν i is the carbon numbers according to its chemical formula. In all cases the time on stream was at least 30 min, so as to ensure that the steady state was always reached. The results showed an acceptable correlation and reproducibility. The error on each data point was below to 5%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Screening of different supports XRD patterns show two intense diffractions corresponding to the (101) and (200) planes of TiO2 anatase at 25.3° and 48.1° ( Fig. 1). For Ru/TiO2-(R+A) and TiO2-P25 diffractions lines at 27.5°, 36°, and 55° corresponding to the (110), (101), and (211) planes of TiO2 rutile are also observed. On ruthenium samples, the (110) and (200) diffractions of the RuO2 rutile phase at ≈ 28°, and ≈ 35° appear. It is worth noting that for all ruthenium samples but for the one supported on TiO2-P25, diffraction lines for both TiO2 and RuO2 rutile phases appear at 27.5 and 28.1º, respectively, indicating the existence of separated phases. However, Ru-supported TiO2-P25 catalyst shows the diffraction line for the TiO2 rutile slightly shifted, appearing at 27.4º and the one for RuO2 rutile appear as a shoulder of the main TiO2 diffraction line at smaller diffraction angles that in pure RuO2 rutile phases. This suggests the formation of a TiO2-RuO2 solid solution in this catalyst. Spinodal transformation of Ti-rich and Ru-rich solid solutions is expected for compositions of ~10 mol% either Ru or Ti containing solid solutions [20]. Upon H2-reduction at 300ºC only the Ru/TiO2-P25 catalyst present an appreciable catalytic activity being ~60% the conversion at 210ºC. Table 3 reports the catalytic activity at this temperature in comparison with the others TiO2 samples. The selectivity is almost 100% at temperatures below 190ºC, with CO conversions lower than 20%, decreasing on increasing temperature. Tauster et al. [21] proposed the concept of strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) in 1978 to describe the drastic changes in the chemisorption properties of Group 8–10 noble metals supported on TiO2 that affects the catalytic behavior in different reactions. The occurrence of an SMSI phenomenon has a direct relationship with the preparation methods of catalysts and Ru loading. An electronic effect, rather than a geometric effect, is probably the origin of this SMSI phenomenon [22]. The performance of TiO2-P25 support on the activity for the selective CO methanation on Ru catalysts has already been highlighted [23]. Although some authors reported better specific activities for the rutile phase [24] the activity of TiO2-P25 support cannot be associated to the presence of the rutile phase but to the support microstructure simultaneously with a SMSI effect. The Ru/TiO2 (R+A) catalyst, containing a similar amount of rutile phase but consisting in a physical mixture of anatase and rutile, present very poor performances. TiO2-P25 materials may be described as a layered-like structure formed by epitaxially grown rutile phased on top of anatase crystals favoring the anatase–rutile contact [25]. This microstructure allows, upon Ru impregnation, the isovalent substitution of Ti cations by Ru ones in the rutile phase forming TiO2-RuO2 solid solutions [26,27]. Using in-situ Raman spectroscopy we have demonstrated that RuO2 growths epitaxially on the TiO2 rutile phase resulting in structured RuO2/RuxTi1−xO2/TiO2 (110) catalyst precursor. H2-reduction of the precursor results in metal Ru nanoparticles with Ti3+ sites in their periphery because of hydrogen spìllover [26]. To determine the transformation of the metal precursor effect on physicochemical properties of TiO2 samples and on activity, thermal decomposition of Ru precursor has been carried out either in synthetic air flow or pure hydrogen (60 mL.min-1 total flow) at 450 ºC for 2 h. For air-decomposed precursor an H2-reduction step at 300 ºC was further performed. H2-TPR profiles of Ru/TiO2-P25 pretreated in synthetic air and/or hydrogen are presented in Fig. 2. Both patterns are very different since one sample is already reduced (hydrogen flow) meanwhile other is oxidized (synthetic air sample). These differences reinforce the existence of changes in the ruthenium particle during the treatment procedure probably in terms of size, accessibility, and/or support interaction. Only single peak of H2 consumption is observed at 76 ºC for H2 treated sample ascribed to the reduction of small portion (9%) of RuO2 that has been re-oxidized under atmosphere conditions. By contrast 89% of reducibility of RuO2 species is obtained for air synthetic treated sample ( Table 4). In this case the first reduction process is observed at 89 ºC. This reduction peak with low intensity at much higher temperature suggests higher RuO2 crystallite size and/or lower proportion of smaller metal Ru0 particles in synthetic air treated sample. Additionally, two reduction peaks at higher temperatures (150 ºC and 186 ºC) are also observed for air synthetic treated sample. Both processes are ascribed to the reduction of RuO2 species interacting in a different way with the support [21]. There are three reduction peaks normally described in the literature for Ru/TiO2: one at ≈ 105 ºC due to the well dispersed amorphous RuO2, other between ≈ 125 °C - 190 °C ascribed to well-dispersed crystalline RuO2, and the other at ≈ 223 °C, due to bulk RuO2 reduction [22]. The estimated crystallites sizes of Ru obtained from applying Scherrer equation on the (101) XRD family planes at 44.01° 2θ results to be 3.8 nm. However, after direct treatment with pure H2, nor Ru peaks could be detected by XRD, pointing to the low crystalline domain size of the Ru nanoparticles produced, under the detection limit of the XRD technique. Differences on SBET, pore volume and pore diameter of these two catalysts respect to one calcined in static air (Table 4) are noticed, which is probably due to different ruthenium phase size. Fig. 3 presents TEM micrographs and particle size distributions obtained for both thermal decomposition procedures on TiO2-P25-based catalyst. The Ru average particle size (Table 4) upon high temperature H2-reduction is much smaller than the one observed after calcination in synthetic air and further reduction at 300ºC. The decrease in the reduction temperature in H2 sample compared to the synthetic air one agrees with the lower crystallite size of RuO2 determined from XRD and confirms changes in the ruthenium particle size of the catalysts during the activation procedure. The formation of the RuxTi1−xO2 solid solution and nanoparticle tendency to nucleate on oxygen surface vacancies will justify the smaller particle size of the H2-decomposed precursor material. Fig. 4 plots the activity and selectivity of Ru/TiO2-P25 catalysts submitted to the two studied precursor decomposition procedures. The air-decomposed precursor result in a more active catalyst that arrives to ~100% CO conversion at 240ºC while the H2-decomposed sample although present activity at much lower temperatures than the air-decomposed one only arrives to CO conversion of 80%. On the contrary, the air-decomposed sample is less active for the hydrogenation of CO2. At 260 ºC, CO2 conversions are 28% and 49% for the air- and H2-decomposed samples, respectively. Therefore, the selectivity is much higher for the air-decomposed material supporting the influence of particle size on the activity and selectivity of Ru catalysts, as early claimed [28–30], although Takenaka et. al. [13] reported higher catalytic activity for small Ru particles sizes. This apparent contradiction may be understood by analyzing the metal dispersion using H2 chemisorption and the SMSI phenomenon. Ru dispersion for the air-decomposed and H2-decomposed precursors are 61% and 26%, respectively. In general CO methanation has been proposed to occur by hydrogenation of carbon formed by its dissociative adsorption [31], while other authors proposed H-assisted dissociation of CO as the key process in the methanation reaction [32]. CO hydrogenation should involve formation of HCO species that is further hydrogenated to hydroxymethylene that dissociates into CH and OH prior to form methane. It is remarkable in this mechanism the role of the adsorbed OH species that reduce the activation barrier to form the initial formyl species. The positive effect of water has been recently highlighted for Ru/Al2O3 catalysts by IR in conditions relevant to the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [33]. This later mechanism is consistent with the previous observation of the kinetic relevance for the reaction of linearly CO adsorbed on Ru sites [34]. On Ru/Al2O3 it has been observed that linearly adsorbed CO species bonded to metal Ru sites are the active species in CO methanation whereas formate species remains on the support as spectators blocking oxygen vacancies and eliminating surface hydroxyls from the support [9]. H-assisted CO activation at high coverages during CO hydrogenation on Ru catalysts is favored on terraces sites of Ru [35], but at low CO coverages direct dissociation in low-coordination sites occur, adsorbed O species resulting from CO dissociation are hydrogenated to adsorbed OH species that intervene in the H-assisted activation of linearly adsorbed CO on Ru terraces [33]. Assuming this model for CO activation the role of support surface hydroxyls seems to be determinant for the activity ad selectivity of Ru/TiO2-P25 catalysts. All these features directly change the SMSI effect. Early works on the hydroxylation degree of TiO2 surfaces [36] pointed out that water desorbs from these surfaces at low temperatures, but a significant concentration of hydroxyls remains even at high temperature. The estimated coverage of hydroxyl groups on TiO2 decreases from 4,9 OH·nm−2 for samples outgassed at ~200ºC to ~0,5 OH·nm−2 for samples outgassed at ~450ºC, but in the presence of water at high temperatures significant surface rehydroxylation takes place [37]. Therefore, by analyzing the Ru/TiO2-P25 calcination temperature the effect of the hydroxylation degree of the support on the activity and selectivity of the catalysts is studied. 3.2 Calcination temperature Ru/TiO2-P25 was thermally treated at different temperatures (300, 400, 450 and 600 ºC) in a synthetic air flow. It must be considered that the support calcination temperature should be higher than 300 ºC for achieving a complete decomposition of Ruthenium (III) nitrosyl nitrate according to thermal decomposition data (not shown). The calcination temperature hardly affects the composition of the RuO2-TiO2 solid solution ( Fig. 5). The (110) diffraction line of the TiO2 rutile phase slightly shifts upon Ru impregnation but its position does not change with the calcination temperature. However, Ru addition favors anatase to rutile phase transformation that, although almost completed at 600 ºC, start to be significative at 400ºC, much lower than the normally reported one (≈ 800 ºC) for TiO2-P25 [26]. Raman spectra of the calcined samples clearly show an intensity increase of the TiO2 rutile absorptions from 400 ºC ( Fig. 6). TPR study evidences that whatever the calcination temperature almost complete Ru reduction is achieved upon H2-reduction at 300ºC (>90% reducibility) but for the highest temperature used, reduction degree is only ~70%. ( Fig. 7). The activity and selectivity of Ru/TiO2-P25 catalysts calcined at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 8. Whatever the support calcination temperature complete CO conversion is achieved at ~240 ºC but Ru catalyst calcined at 600 ºC reaches 100% CO conversion at ~300 ºC. It is noteworthy that at temperatures higher than ~240 ºC the CO conversion slightly decreases (97–98% CO conversions), which indicates the reverse water gas shift reaction starts to play a role [38]. Besides this, the main differences in the CO conversion curves may be ascribed to differences in mass transport because of thermal treatment affecting the textural properties. Upon calcination at 600 ºC the support crystallite size considerably increases, and the surface area is drastically reduced ( Table 5). However, chemisorption analyses show that all samples have a similar Ru dispersion, with Ru particle sizes between 1.3 and 1.6 nm. However, despite the similarities in Ru particle size, the selectivity strongly depends on the thermal treatment of the support. This behavior cannot be explained based on the active phase particle size statistically identical but on the support properties. In order to clarify this, an in situ Raman Study under different methanation reaction atmospheres at 220ºC was carried out over the Ru/TiO2-P25 catalyst first calcined at 400ºC and then reduced at 300 ºC in H2 ( Fig. 9). The spectrum under a CO2:H2:N2 atmosphere presents bands at 404, 526, 647 and 743 cm−1 that indicates the coexistence of the rutile and anatase phases of TiO2 as well as the presence of surface Ti3+-OH groups characterized by the broad band at 743 cm−1 [26]. Although CO2 methanation activity at 220 ºC is quite low and might explain the absence of bands associated to adsorbed species, on increasing the reaction temperature this support spectrum is not altered (not shown). On the contrary, if the methanation of only CO is considered, the Raman spectrum is dominated by bands at 1595, 1504, 1356 and broad signals at 1119 and 743 cm−1 [26]. The bands at 1119 and 1504 cm−1 may be ascribed to single and double C-O bonds, respectively, and the bands at 1595 and 1356 associated to the G and D bands of graphite, respectively, clearly accounts for CO dissociation on the metal surface. The relatively higher intensity of the D band with respect to the G one points a low graphitization of surface carbon as evidenced by the presence of C-H stretching modes at 2,660; 2,900 and 3,170 cm−1 ascribed to HxCO, CH3CO and/or CHx- and -CH2 = CH2 species, respectively. The presence of these species clearly points to a H-assisted CO dissociation mechanism. A similar Raman spectrum is observed during the hydrogenation of CO and CO2 mixtures but the G bands are now absent and the G:D intensity ratio is higher than for the methanation of CO alone. This clearly indicates that the presence of CO2 in the reaction mixture enhances the reactivity of the adsorbed CHx species influenced by the support effect. By adding water to the COx mixture, the main difference in the Raman spectrum besides the lower intensity of the carbon bands with respect to the TiO2 ones is the broader character of the D and G bands as well as the presence of a weak absorption at 1119 cm−1 indicating that the presence of water favors the reactivity of the adsorbed carbonaceous species. This is related to OH surface groups. The role of OH surface groups on the activation of CO has been demonstrated by Gunasooriya et al. [39], in their DFT study OH groups adsorbed on the metal surface protonates adsorbed CO resulting in HCO that is easily hydrogenated to hydroxyl methylene that dissociates with a reduced activation barrier into adsorbed CH groups. The role of support hydroxyl groups in transferring or accepting protons to adsorbed molecules o metal active phases has been previously described [9,33,40]. The main differences between catalysts on modifying the support calcination temperature are the percentage of rutile phase as evidenced by the Raman spectra and the hydroxylation degree. TiO2 surface react with CO2 leading to the formation of bicarbonate species that are further hydrogenated to adsorbed formate species by hydrogen spillover. It has been shown that monodentate formate species adsorbed on TiO2-P25 samples rapidly decomposes, while the bidentate species coordinated to both anatase and rutile phase particles are only slowly decomposed [41]. The decomposition pattern of these formate species takes place on rutile (110) surfaces at ~300ºC following a complex decomposition pattern [42]. While hydroxyls group remains on the anatase surface as temperatures as high as 450ºC [43] on rutile surfaces desorption of water molecules from recombination of the surface hydroxyl groups occurs at ~250ºC [44,45]. On the other hand, if CO remained in the syngas, methanation of CO2 is retarded. Nawdali et. al [46] demonstrated that the CO species are directly adsorbed on Ru sites and then the hydrogenation to CH4 occurs in the temperature range of 170–205ºC. In the presence of adsorbed CO on the surface, hydrogen is adsorbed on other sites aside from those involved in the absence of CO. Then CO is dissociated, leading to active and inactive carbon species, where the former is stepwise methanated to CHx species and finally to CH4. Inui et. al [47] prepared Ru-Ni-La2O3 catalyst for CO and CO2 methanation and found that CO2 methanation was completely retarded until CO has been converted to methane. This behavior could not be observed using fewer active catalysts, i.e., both CO and CO2 were converted into methane at higher temperatures. In our case the selectivity for CO methanation (SCO) against CO2 methanation remained at 100% until 20% of CO conversion is achieved with Ru/TiO2-P25. Although it is showing the appearance of the consequence of the XCO2 apparition (decay of the SCO) at higher XCO. Small differences at low reaction temperatures are observed with the solids calcined at temperatures lower than 400ºC. However, when higher calcination temperatures are used the selectivity decreases and the CO2 conversion starts at 220ºC. Increasing the reaction temperature, the formation of CO2 is favoured. Fig. 8 also shows the selectivity to CH4 (SCH4) vs CO conversion (XCO) with the temperature of calcination. The selectivity decreases from 97% to ≈ 95% reaching a minimum at XCO close to 10%. After that the selectivity increases until 100% simultaneously with the CO2 methanation. This CO2 activity is faster for the catalysts calcined at 600°C than the others. Similar trends were observed for Panagiotopoulou et.al with Ru/Al2O3 catalysts [12,23]. The minimum SCH4 was observed just when the CO2 methanation starts. After that, both the SCH4 and XCO2 increased. These reinforced the observation that the SCH4 is more favoured by the CO2 methanation than CO methanation. It has been observed that 100% of SCH4 is reached when XCO is completed since the CO2 methanation starts and therefore the selectivity to CH4 increases. In our case the thermal effect seems to be very important to control the metal particle size and the anatase: rutile TiO2 particles growth. They affect the metal dispersion and therefore the activity in methanation reaction. Kwak et al. [48] suggested that the reaction mechanism is different on small particles that are atomically dispersed and the larger Ru ones. Single Ru atoms, or interfacial Ru, favor CO formation, while Ru clusters, which are able to supply large amounts of atomic hydrogen to this process, favor the formation of CH4. The CO2 conversion is promoted at low reaction temperatures for the catalysts calcined above 450ºC and 600ºC. This observation is coherent with the results obtained from the physicochemical characterization. As higher the calcination temperature, higher the sintering phenomena, higher crystallite size of the active phase, lower dispersion and lower reducibility of active phase. This also indicates that the unbeneficial effect of a high calcination temperature is exerted through the size changes observed for the active phase and through a change on reducibility of the RuO2 phase. The active species in the methanation reaction are the reduced states of Ru over TiO2 obtained after an in situ thermal treatment under H2 at 300ºC. In fact, the adsorption and dissociation of CO on centers of Ru0 determines the catalytic behavior since the reduction of the RuO2-TiO2 generates active Ru0-Ti3+ centers [26]. Additionally, the size of the RuO2 phase at different calcination temperatures indicates unambiguously that the nature of the support dictates the behaviour of the RuO2 particles, and this is correlated with the catalytic performance. As said before, the methanation is thought to be a structure-sensitive reaction, since different physical states of active species have been reported to have different intrinsic activities. The importance of size and distribution of the active nanoparticles has been proven in the case of ammonia synthesis with Ru particles, and CO2 methanation with Rh/Ru particles under mild conditions [49–51]. The sintering behaviour is a factor influencing the catalytic activity. Subsequently, the diffusion of RuO2 nanoparticles leads to two different phenomena in terms of sintering: isotropic growth of RuO2 crystals on the anatase or epitaxial growth of the RuO2 layer on rutile. Not excessive sinter and the stabilization must occur through RuO2 and TiO2 epitaxial interactions. RuO2 is thus spread on the TiO2 rutile surface, with anatase particles acting as diluent and preventing the TiO2 rutile–RuO2–TiO2 rutile stacking. Lower stabilization of the metal particles and higher sintering appear as the anatase TiO2 phase decreases as consequence of the transition to rutile with the calcination temperature. TiO2 anatase particles promote the Ru migration to rutile and imped the excessive sintering of TiO2 rutile particles [52]. In our case CH4 is mainly produced throughout the hydrogenation of CO2 that is favoured at higher calcination temperature with the consequence of increasing the metal phase size. This result is coherent with similar studies [53,54]. DRIFTs experiments with CO and CO2 mixture on Rh catalyst [55] showed that the adsorption/dissociation of CO2 is carried out on metal centers to produce Rh-CO and Rh-(CO)2 species. Rh-(CO)2 are instable and dissociate until CO[adsorbed] and O[adsorbed]. In turn, the CO[adsorbed] is dissociated on metal centers until O[adsorbed] and C[adsorbed]. Therefore, the number of Ru-C and Ru-O sites should increase after CO2 dissociation more than after CO dissociation. Therefore, the Ru-C centres are necessary to form CH4. According to the results, the calcination temperature determines the active phase size and its distribution, as well as the rutile and anatase concentrations and their size. All of them influence the catalytic behaviour. The characterization and activity results demonstrate that the calcination at 400ºC in synthetic air is an appropriate thermal treatment since the physicochemical properties of the solids are well controlled. Moreover, the transition to rutile phase is not so high ant growth of the metal particle by the stabilising effect of the anatase is improved. Concerning to the activity behaviour, the CO2 methanation is low at 400ºC and the selectivity to CO methanation is higher at higher conversions of CO respect to other temperature (i.e 450ºC). 3.3 Ru loading The metal loading also seems to be another important parameter that determines the metal particle size / dispersion and therefore the selectivity of the catalysts. However, there is no a general agreement in the literature about the ideal metal loading for the high CO methanation. In the following section the results of the metal loading study are shown. These were carried out on Ru/TiO2-P25 samples thermally treated in synthetic air at 400ºC. Concentration of Ru of 2, 5, 10 and 20 wt% were studied. XRF measurements on reduced samples at 300ºC revealed that the real Ru contents on Ru/TiO2 powder catalysts are very close to the nominal values ( Table 6). It also shows the textural properties of the solids. The changes are related to the interaction between the metal phase and the anatase: rutile phases with the Ru concentration. At much higher Ru loading (20 wt%) the structure collapses and the textural properties decrease. Similar observations were pointed out by Ismail et. al [56] with similar catalysts containing 10 wt% of Ru. In this case an excessive growth of the metal phase was observed simultaneously with decreasing in textural properties. In our case the XRD results confirm the sintering of the metal particles at higher concentration of Ru. With 2 wt% of Ru the no observation of RuO2 peaks agrees with its low amount and/or lower particles size. However, with 20 wt% of Ru the crystallite size of RuO2 is 24 nm with respect to 14.8 obtained with 5 wt%. On the other hand, at higher Ru loading lower sintering of TiO2 anatase and TiO2 rutile phases is observed. The changes observed in the textural properties suggest that the transformation to rutile phase is favored at higher metal concentration. This could be promoted by the Ru concentration simultaneously with a thermal effect. To confirm this observation in-situ XRD at different temperatures were done. Fig. 10 shows in-situ XRD in synthetic air from 100 °C to 900 °C for 5, 10 and 20 wt% Ru/TiO2-P25 samples. For sake of comparison, the bare support is also shown. In all cases the diffractions peaks of TiO2 anatase and TiO2 rutile phases are observed simultaneously with RuO2 peaks. At higher calcination temperatures the intensity of rutile peaks increases whilst the anatase peaks decreases. This indicates the structural modification of the support with the temperature. The bare support TiO2-P25 requires higher temperatures to induce the transformation anatase→ rutile. After the addition of Ru, this transformation is shifted at lower temperatures. Higher Ru loading induces higher transformation to rutile at much lower temperatures. At 400ºC the selected calcination temperature, the anatase concentration is very similar for both 5 wt% and 10 wt% of Ru (74% of vs 70% respectively). Despite this small difference the anatase concentration effect on the RuO2 size and dispersion is seems to be important since anatase phase is necessary to stabilize the metal particles by controlling the excessive metal growth. The sintering of RuO2 particles increases for 10 wt% of Ru with respect to 5 wt%. (22 nm vs 14.8, respectively). Therefore, with 10 wt% of Ru higher Ru particle size and higher crystallinity of the active phase are obtained. Fig. 11 shows the metal loading effect on the SCO methanation with Ru/TiO2 catalysts. Higher concentration of Ru species promotes the CO2 conversion at temperatures above 200ºC increasing with the reaction temperature until 300ºC. To favor the selective CO methanation in Ru catalysts. Fujita et. al [57] studied the competitive methanation in a mixed 10 vol% CO and 10 vol% CO2 in balance H2 with Ru/SiO2 catalyst. They observed that CO2 methanation rate at 200ºC is 4.6 times faster than the CO methanation rate. Over et. al [58] pointed out that changing the CO/CO2 ratio in the gas feed to higher values than 2:1 will deteriorate the overall activity due to blocking the surface by CO molecules. These facts have strongly indicated that when more highly active catalysts are used the preferential methanation of CO could be achieved prior to CO2 methanation at lower temperature range, and also that the ratio CO/CO2 must be carefully adjusted. Fig. 11 also shows the selectivity data vs XCO (%). It is clear that the most selective catalysts to CO methanation is 10 wt% Ru/TiO2-P25. Despite the sintering of the metal particles the activity and selectivity are promoted. Again, we observe that the selectivity SCO increases with the ruthenium particle size of Ru. This result unequivocally shows that the metal-support interaction is affected by the metal content and the physicochemical characteristics of the support. This interaction changes with the size and location of the ruthenium particles. The methanation reaction is sensitive to Ru size if CO dissociation is rate-limited [59,60]. Hu et al. [61] measured an increase in CO2 conversion with increases the Ru loading on TiO2 support until ca. 3% before declining, while the selectivity for CO and CH4 remained unchanged. Similarly, Kwak et al. [48] found that the TOF for CH4 increased with Ru loading (0.1–5%) on Al2O3. However, an opposite trend was observed for the TOF and selectivity of CO. Lange et al. [62] also found that increasing the loading of Ru on a ZrO2 support, from 1% to 3%, increases the CO2 conversion from 93.9 to ca. 97%. Verykios and col. [12,22] described that the TOF values increase with the increase in the particle size in methanation reaction. Rosseti et al. [63] demonstrated that the selective methanation of CO is sensitive to the particle size and concentration of Ru. There is a concentration of the ruthenium in which the number of active sites is optimum. Beyond this concentration, the number of active sites decreases, and the agglomeration of the metal particles occurs. Therefore, the location and size of the ruthenium particles determine the catalytic behavior for methanation reaction. Ru particles of 9 nm have been identified as the most actives ones for the CO dissociation probably by the existence of the so-called B5 sites [64]. These sites are composed by five consecutive ruthenium atoms, three of them are located in the same layer and the other two are arranged in the superior layer, forming a monoatomic step in a terrace of Ru. In our case, results of XRD for 10 wt% of Ru with the temperature in H2 atmosphere at 300 °C demonstrated that the crystal size of Ru0 particles is 8.7 nm exposing the (101) plane at 2θ = 43.97°. This crystal size is close to the reported ideal value for particles of Ru [65] and it was also verified by TEM microscopy. This explains the higher selectivity observed with 10 wt% of Ru at higher temperatures. This catalyst favours the selectivity of the methanation, decreasing the occurrence of the CO2 methanation and RWGS reaction, saving the excessive consumption of H2. In addition, for industrial applications, the lifetime of the catalysts load is of vital importance. Depending of the operational conditions, sometimes a large excess of catalysts load is economically interesting, because the price of the catalyst if lower than the costs derived from the process stop. This is even more evident for operational systems where start-stop cycles are mandatory (for instance, for portable devices, where PEMFC and structured reactors can be used). Thus, despite the higher price of the catalysts, the use of a high amount of Ru could be sustainable and economically justifiable. 4 Conclusions This study remarks the importance of support surface hydroxyls seems for both the activity and selectivity of Ru/TiO2 catalysts for CO activation. Adsorbed O species resulting from CO dissociation are hydrogenated to adsorbed OH species that intervene in the H-assisted activation of adsorbed CO on Ru catalysts increasing the activity. The changes in the activity and selectivity of the CO methanation reaction can also be related with the observed changes in the ruthenium particle size, as evidenced by TPR, XRD and TEM results, that modify the metal-support interaction. The results demonstrated that the crystalline phase of the support as well as the atmosphere of the treatment, the calcination temperature and the Ru loading determine the dispersion and size of the metal phase. All of them modify the structural and textural characteristics of the final solid as a result of anatase → rutile transformation and RuO2 + TiO2 solid solution formation. The catalytic behavior is explained by the formation of more active Ru species on TiO2 support, resulting in active and selective catalysts where the suppression of the RWGS reaction was observed. In this case 10 wt% Ru/TiO2-P25 thermally treated at 400 °C with synthetic air favored the CO selectivity, decreasing the occurrence of the CO2 methanation and RWGS reaction, saving the excessive consumption of H2. Thus, despite the higher price of the catalysts, the use of a high amount of Ru could be sustainable and economically justifiable. Here the increasing in RuO2 crystallite size favors the catalytic behavior but after a previous reduction protocol. At much higher calcination temperature and Ru loading, higher the sintering phenomena, higher crystallite size of the active phase, lower dispersion, lower reducibility of active phase and lower activity and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: The aim of this work was to clarify the effect of the support on CO selective methanation with Ru/TiO2 catalysts. TPR, XRD and TEM measurements confirmed that the changes in the activity and selectivity should be ascribed to anatase:rutile ratio, RuO2 +TiO2 solid solution formation, as well as the metal content and the thermal treatment used. All these characteristics result in active and selective catalysts in which the suppression of the reverse water gas shift reaction was observed. The catalytic performance must be explained by both the formation of more active Ru species as a result of support influence and the higher Ru dispersion. The study allows to conclude that for CO activation the role of support surface hydroxyls seems to be determinant for both the activity and selectivity of Ru/TiO2 catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of support surface hydroxyls on selective CO methanation with Ru based catalysts
